channel.title: Laws
channel.description: If there was ONE law you could change, what would it be and why?

item.title: Laws
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

imsuperman05:

What type of drugs are we talking about legalizing here? Cocaine, speed, heroine, meth, etc.?

well as previously stated, I’m for the legalisation of all drugs for a variety of reasons but most importantly because it allows people to get the help they need, there’s a bigger discussion to be had on this topic but to keep it succinct: legalising drugs reduces the numbers of drug users, fatalities and drug-related crimes, it has been proven time and time again with large case studies such as those in portugal and the netherlands to name a couple

even if we ignore everything else, by looking for people on welfare who may have drug problems you’re demonising the most vulnerable people in society, I don’t quite see what you hope to achieve by making a bad situation even worse and thinking everything will turn out for the best

Kidpaparoach:

Its effective for people that do drugs on night outs though? I remember I smoked a joint and got drug tested and hey presto it worked, but as you said cannabis is easy to find out. Sorry for the late reply.

to understand why drug testing isn’t effective you need to look at the methodology of how drugs are tested, as I’ve stated many drugs don’t stay in your system for a long time and to find these drugs you actively need to search for them (costing money for resources and many, MANY man hours)

codeine, ghb, heroin, many opiates and oxycodone all stay in your system for as little as 1-2 days, meanwhile amphetamines, cocaine, ketamine and methamphetamine all stay in your system for up to 4 days, benzodiazepines only stay in your system for 3 days while lsd and ecstasy stay in your system for up to 5 days

so, in as little as 5 days, most of the drugs taken recreationally will be out of your system, it’s only a few other drugs that last longer such as cannabis, methadone and phencyclidine that generally stay in your system for longer than a week, so while we can test for those substances and find them if they were taken less than a week ago, you can’t actively search for those drugs unless you do random drug tests on a frequent basis and even then you’re looking at a good lot of the population who aren’t going to be caught by these tests unless you ramp up the tests, so to find a most likely minority of welfare recipients who take drugs you are now subjecting all welfare recipients to frequent drug tests where false positives may occur and if the welfare recipient can’t make a test (people on welfare have lives too you know) then they’d be suspected for taking drugs and possibility lose their only financial support

and what exactly will be caused by spending millions monthly testing all welfare recipients for drugs? you stop what is likely a small minority of people taking drugs and instead of saving money by stopping their welfare, you now send them to jail where they are almost CERTAINLY going to cost the system tens and hundreds of times MORE in financial costs than if they had spent their welfare money on drugs, and if these people have children you now have to spend money for childcare for them which again is only going to make a bad situation much worse

so for a tl;dr: to “save” money where welfare recipients spend it on drugs, you would have to spend millions on drug testing, millions on sending them to already overpopulated prisons and millions on childcare, and you’ll have to spend millions more on rehab and millions more making sure they don’t resort back to drug use, the guise that this saves money is often stated as a case by people who are opposed to welfare to begin with, not exactly an unbiased source

Read full topic

item.title: Laws
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=586620.msg4170195#msg4170195 date=1354213813]Its effective? Been drug tested before and it worked, or do you mean its ineffective in a different mannerism?

drug testing is ridiculously ineffective, the only drugs that are detected are drugs that are being tested for and in many cases the drug will no longer be present in your system after 4 days, most drugs are gone in a week and detoxing may or may not reduce the time that the drugs in your system, it’s only certain drugs such as cannabis under HEAVY usage that the drug stays in the system for more like a month, and given that cannabis is starting to be legalised in several states that isn’t an issue

so, given that we now know that a) drug testing is expensive (commercial testing is $25 a pop, and like I say these kits only detect what they actually search for) and b) not always effective unless used frequently (for some drugs, every 3 days, others every 9 days) you’ll be spending a love LOAD per person to make sure they remain drug free for the purpose of “saving money”, you’ll end up wasting more money on drug tests than these people spend on drugs, not to mention the fact that the whole idea that welfare users are a bunch of moochers and druggies is completely baseless

it wasnt sarcastic

I wasn’t being sarcastic.

well whoop de doo excessive periods (>3) and/or 2 periods is damn near globally recognised as sarcasm

What brilliant solution do you have then?

I don’t claim to have a brilliant solution but I see you offering a solution to be a bad solution for a problem that may or not be there

hell as bowser pointed out, if drugs weren’t illegal and therefore weren’t inflated to ridiculous prices, such a problem wouldn’t be a problem anymore[/quote]
Its effective for people that do drugs on night outs though? I remember I smoked a joint and got drug tested and hey presto it worked, but as you said cannabis is easy to find out. Sorry for the late reply.

Read full topic

well whoop de doo excessive periods (>3) and/or 2 periods is damn near globally recognised as sarcasm

[/quote]
I honestly did not know that. Never even heard of that lol

What type of drugs are we talking about legalizing here? Cocaine, speed, heroine, meth, etc.?

Even if cannabis is legal in several states, it still does not make it okay to use it in states where it is not legal.[/quote]
I would legalize everything in it weak normal forms, and compete out organized crime. Make laws about drugs the same way you make laws again alcohol. You wouldn’t check if welfare recipients drink alcohol? If so, good look with your daily testing of everyone on welfare.

Read full topic

@The_Un-Named wrote:

Kidpaparoach:

Its effective? Been drug tested before and it worked, or do you mean its ineffective in a different mannerism?

drug testing is ridiculously ineffective, the only drugs that are detected are drugs that are being tested for and in many cases the drug will no longer be present in your system after 4 days, most drugs are gone in a week and detoxing may or may not reduce the time that the drugs in your system, it’s only certain drugs such as cannabis under HEAVY usage that the drug stays in the system for more like a month, and given that cannabis is starting to be legalised in several states that isn’t an issue

so, given that we now know that a) drug testing is expensive (commercial testing is $25 a pop, and like I say these kits only detect what they actually search for) and b) not always effective unless used frequently (for some drugs, every 3 days, others every 9 days) you’ll be spending a FUCK LOAD per person to make sure they remain drug free for the purpose of “saving money”, you’ll end up wasting more money on drug tests than these people spend on drugs, not to mention the fact that the whole idea that welfare users are a bunch of moochers and druggies is completely baseless

asshole_rule:

it wasnt sarcastic

imsuperman05:

I wasn’t being sarcastic.

well whoop de doo excessive periods (>3) and/or 2 periods is damn near globally recognised as sarcasm

imsuperman05:

What brilliant solution do you have then?

I don’t claim to have a brilliant solution but I see you offering a solution to be a bad solution for a problem that may or not be there

hell as bowser pointed out, if drugs weren’t illegal and therefore weren’t inflated to ridiculous prices, such a problem wouldn’t be a problem anymore

item.title: Laws
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:54, topic:469424”][quote author=Niall link=topic=586620.msg4169435#msg4169435 date=1354098914]

[quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=586620.msg4166452#msg4166452 date=1353785330]

Requiring mandatory regular drug screening for people receiving assistance from the government
A “common sense” clause to everything. For example, if you’re a smoker, and you smoke regularly (even socially), you lose the ability to sue the manufacturer if you get lung cancer, or anything that can be directly attributed to smoking.
[/quote]these.
Another one would be for people receiving assistant from the government (such as welfare, food stamps, etc.) to be investigated fully to make sure that they 100% cannot afford it to where they are not spending money on shit that they do not need for survival. I phrased it confusingly, but I just want those people that are sitting on their asses living off the government to be punished or stopped. For example, people on food stamps with a damn Iphone or expensive android or any other expensive technology that aren’t needed.

so to combat people wasting government money, you want to make sure they aren’t wasting money by wasting dozens of times MORE money making sure they aren’t wasting money?

ok
[/quote]ooh that’s true… i didn’t think about that…[/quote]
Good. Now rethink everything you think about politics. Then join your local communist party. Have fun :). Just make sure it is not CPUSA or Trotskyists.

Read full topic

item.title: Laws
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“lostmyphat, post:51, topic:469424”][quote author=JavaTC link=topic=586620.msg4166069#msg4166069 date=1353727612]

which we are all overpaying for

Please enlighten us on how you’re an economic expert. Show us your plan to get us out of debt while lower our taxes.
[/quote] show me how the last 4 yrs of taxing has gotten us out of our debt. Oh wait, it got worse…[/quote]
STOP TAXES ALTOGETHER, THEY BAD, THEY COST MUNNEY

No but seriously, I don’t think you understand how fragile an economy is. Why do you think just a few years of bad budgeting has put us $16T in debt? It doesn’t really matter though, as long as the rest of the world believes we can pay off our debt. Once they start believing we can’t pay it off… Well, then we have a serious problem on our hands.

Read full topic

item.title: Laws
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:48, topic:469424”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=586620.msg4166939#msg4166939 date=1353811621]

Being able to buy beer on Sunday. Keep your church out of my liquor store!

Just buy you liquor on Saturday. I have no problem with not being able to buy stuff on Sundays, so I don’t see your problem.

There’s a few liquor stores near me who are big god people and have their stores shut on a sunday.

What are the problems closing all stores at Sundays?

So if I run out of alcohol on the Saturday I can get some on Sunday. Sunday is not Sunday without a few cans.
[/quote]
You should plan your drunkenness. Or maybe not drink as much on Saturday.[/quote]
I’m usually like “I WILL LEAVE 4 CANS FOR TOMORROW” then about 15 mins later I’m like “I WILL BE FINE WITH 3 CANS” and so forth, lol. I end up going to the supermarket and getting a 12 crate and that suits me fine. It’d be easier just going down the street though.

Read full topic
